SEARCH
Module org.jandle
Package org.jandle.api.http

Interface Chain

public interface Chain
Represents a filter execution chain for processing an HTTP request.

A Chain controls the sequential invocation of request filters and the final request handler. Each filter receives the same Request and Response instances and may decide whether to continue processing by invoking next(Request, Response).

Execution Model

  • Filters are executed in the order they were registered
  • Each filter must explicitly call next(Request, Response) to pass control to the next filter or handler

Short-Circuiting

A filter may terminate processing early by:
  • Sending a response directly
  • Not invoking next(Request, Response)

This enables common cross-cutting concerns such as authentication, logging, rate limiting, and request validation.

Error Handling

Implementations may propagate IOException if an error occurs while advancing the chain or writing the response.

Thread Safety

Chain instances are not required to be thread-safe and are typically scoped to a single request execution.
See Also:

  • Response

    next(Request request, Response response)
    Continues execution of the chain.

  • Method Details

    • next

      void next(Request request, Response response) throws IOException
      Continues execution of the chain.

      If there are remaining filters, the next filterâ€™s doFilter(...) method is invoked. Otherwise, control is passed to the final handler.

      Filters are responsible for explicitly calling this method if they wish to allow the request to proceed.

      Parameters:
      request - the current HTTP request
      response - the HTTP response being built
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs while processing the request or response
